Visualizing Sunlight

Eagleview | Lead Design | 2019

As the lead designer, I revamped Eagleview‘s report to enhance its communication and serve as an effective sales tool for solar installers. A key focus was the Total Solar Resource Fraction (TSRF) views, a complex visual challenge to determine optimal year-round solar panel placement. With minimal direction from a PM, I tackled this using existing tools, including a DOS app for testing.

New Design

I designed the report to visually guide solar contractors and customers toward maximum efficiency placement. The initial printed version, created in MS Word with improved tables and charts, preceded a planned web-based update.

Research

I conducted hallway user testing, asking uninvolved co-workers to identify the sunniest roof areas, which shaped my color choices. Using a DOS app, I generated research images and tested various schemes.

Early concepts included:

Multi-color

Discrete colors for irradiance ranges seemed promising, but nearly half the participants couldn‘t identify the brightest.

Adjacent Warm Colors

A transition between adjacent colors was tested, but some reversed the ‘hottest‘ shade despite a labeled key, with the lightest intended as sunniest.

Monochromatic

Shifting focus to darkness, I created a blue monochromatic heat map. Blue effectively conveyed shadow and light, performing best in testing over other colors.

Gridlock

A square-foot grid aided measurement but darkened the blue, making it look drab.

Dot-to-Dot

Inspired by sketchbook grids, I switched to a dot-grid at intersections. This reduced color distortion, letting the blues appear cleaner.

Challenges and Solutions

Beyond color and grid issues, I enhanced the report‘s MS Word tables, charts, and graphs, limited by the tool‘s capabilities. I also recommended line color and grid pattern changes, though these couldn‘t be controlled in the DOS app.

Outcome

The report remains in use today, largely unchanged since my 2019 design.
